It is my personal opinion that bitcoin has a small chance of becoming priced significantly higher than it is today. While the chance is small, the upside is high enough that It's worth making the investment as part of a diversified strategy.

This is similar to betting on a startup. Because I believe the chance is so small, I would not want to have a significant portion of my wealth in bitcoin. I would invest only a small percentage of my wealth in bitcoin. I would not try to buy and sell it like a day trader. Because of bitcoin’s price volatility, I would not want to take that risk. Instead, I would buy it and hold it as a long term investment.

Opportunity

If bitcoin was widely used as a currency it would most likely be priced significantly higher than it is today. It would likely be priced higher because it could only be widely used as a currency if a lot of people bought it first. The increase in demand for bitcoin would cause the price to rise.

Risks

Bitcoin is still a relatively new technology and there are a lot of potential risks associated with investing in it. Below are some of the biggest risks I see facing bitcoin as it pertains to become a widely adopted currency.

a. Government Regulation

If the government were to make it illegal to own or use bitcoin, it would likely deter people from doing so. The government’s position on bitcoin is not clear. But it does seem plausible that the government could make it illegal, as the currency is somewhat competitive to government. The government could also try to regulate it and/or tax it the way it does other industries.
Depending on the specifics of the regulation, it could potentially make it less attractive to own bitcoin.

b. Limited Adoption

If there are very few people who accept payment in the form of bitcoin, there would be less incentive to own bitcoin. If you could use bitcoin for any purchase the way you can use existing currency, it would be more practical to own. If you can’t spend the bitcoin, you would still need to own some other currency.

Lack of adoption is a risk, however more and more consumers and merchants are buying, using and selling bitcoin, all around the world. Bitcoin has a “network effect.” Just as more of your friends start using facebook, you are more likely to start using Facebook, and as more and more of your life and personal data are stored on Facebook you are less likely to stop using Facebook.

c. Volatility


The above chart was sourced from

Bitcoin News, Prices, Charts, Guides & Analysis - CoinDesk [ http://coindesk.com/ ]

. The date range is November 1st 2013, to May 25th 2014. As you can see, the price has been quite volatile. An important risk factor for the future of Bitcoin is whether it will can achieve a stable value. Stable prices are an important quality of a successful currency. If prices are too volatile, it becomes risk to own the currency, accept it as a form of payment, etc.

d. Lack of Liquidity

According to Investopedia, liquidity is “The degree to which an asset or security can be bought or sold in the market without affecting the asset's price. Liquidity is characterized by a high level of trading activity. Assets that can be easily bought or sold are known as liquid assets.”

If an asset is “liquid,” it means it is easy to convert it into cash quickly. For example, large market cap stocks often have very high trading volumes, so you can find a buyer or seller pretty quickly. Conversely, if an asset is “illiquid,” it is hard to convert it to cash quickly. For example, a house is fairly illiquid. It can take months to find a buyer for a house.

Liquid assets are more attractive than illiquid assets, all else being equal. Bitcoin has yet to be widely adopted or traded by the general population. However, bitcoin exchanges aggregate supply and demand and make it easier to convert between bitcoin and cash.

e. Safety of Supporting Services/Products

There are a plethora of products and services that make traditional currency more usable. There are banks (for storage and lending), credit card companies, wallets (for portability), payment processors, etc. Similar products and services are needed and offered to make bitcoin more usable.

Mt. Gox recently declared bankruptcy and it led to a lot of public criticism over bitcoin as a viable currency.

However, more and more companies are starting to support the bitcoin ecosystem. As new firms enter the market, competition forces out the unsafe companies and enables the safe companies to survive and grow.

d. Competition

Other cryptocurrencies could erode bitcoin’s market share. More currencies in the market means more competition, and capital spread accordingly. Reaching “critical mass” could be quite productive for bitcoin. Competing currencies make it more difficult to do so. There are many other digital currencies or cryptocurrencies, and new ones are being created regularly. The last chapter of this book contains a brief list of some of them.

The fact that many people are asking if bitcoin is a bubble, or believe that is, is an indication that it's not a bubble. An en economic bubble is usually coupled with near universal belief about rising prices. Housing circa the early 2000s and

higher education [ http://www.amazon.com/Popping-Higher-Education-Bubble-Impending-ebook/dp/B00JLUSUN4 ]

in 2014 provide illustrations of near universal beliefs.

There are still only a very limited number of people who even know what bitcoin is, let alone are buying it or believe it's price will keep rising. I don’t think we are anywhere near universal belief that the price of bitcoin will continue to rise.

Bitcoin still only has minuscule value as compared to global currency. If bitcoin were to replace a larger percentage of global currency it would be worth much more than it's worth now. If it were to replace global currency...I can't even guess how much it would be worth.

I agree that it only has value because people think it has value...but the US dollar only has value because people think it has value too. Same with gold. Same with antiques.

I do believe there is a decent chance that bitcoin completely collapses and eventually becomes worth close to nothing. That doesn’t mean it is currently a bubble. It may mean that price is slightly higher than intrinsic value, but not necessarily.

Just because there is a chance that it could become worth nothing, doesn’t mean it should be priced at nothing. For example, a lottery ticket has a high probability of being worth nothing, but there is a chance that it could be worth millions, so therefore there is some value in taking that chance. There is a high probability that a startup will fail, but because of the potential reward if it is successful, it is worth it to some to start or invest in a startup.

Potential Bitcoin Investment Strategy

As part of a large diversified portfolio, my personal opinion is that bitcoin could make for an attractive investment opportunity.

answers.html:
Bitcoin provides a sound and predictable monetary policy that can be verified by anyone.

Bitcoin’s monetary policy is one of its most important features. It’s possible to see when new bitcoins are created when a transaction is created, or how many bitcoins are in circulation.

Bitcoins can be sent from anywhere in the world to anywhere else in the world. No bank can block payments or close your account. Bitcoin is censorship-resistant money.

Bitcoin makes cross-border payments possible, and also provides an easy way for people to escape failed government monetary policy.

A global currency like Bitcoin will have the same impact on finance and the global economy.

If you understand the potential impact of Bitcoin, it won’t be hard to understand why investing in bitcoin may be a good idea.

Anyone who bought Bitcoin and held it for five years or more made significant returns on investment. If you bought Bitcoin in December 2015, you could have bought it for 400 USD; if you sold it five years later for 28,828 USD, that would be a 72x gain!

The stock market does not perform like this. Amazon is a success story for stock market traders and it would only give you a 5x gain.

Bitcoin has continuously proven itself to be the greatest investment of the decade.

Before you buy Bitcoin, you need to make sure you are ready for it. Bitcoin is a highly volatile asset and if you buy at the top and sell at the bottom, you can lose a lot of money.

My rule of thumb is that if you can’t afford to buy Bitcoin and hold it for five years or longer, you shouldn’t buy it. If you end up needing extra money because of an emergency and have to sell your Bitcoin, it just might not happen at a good time. What if someone put their whole life savings into Bitcoin in December 2020 and then desperately needed the money in May 2021? They would have lost a whopping percentage of their life savings!

  • If you don’t have enough money in savings to cover emergency expenses, you shouldn’t buy Bitcoin.
  • If you don’t have healthcare, you shouldn’t buy Bitcoin.
  • If you have a large and expected expense coming up, you shouldn’t buy Bitcoin.
  • If you are not emotionally stable, you shouldn’t buy Bitcoin.
  • If you can’t buy Bitcoin and hold onto it for years even though it’s losing value, then you shouldn’t buy Bitcoin.

No. It's a *terrible* idea to invest in bitcoin unless you are looking at hyperinflation or as part of some sort of hedge.

1) You can make money *trading* bitcoin
2) You can make money *using* bitcoin - I'm part of a venture that is using bitcoin to help Chinese investors make overseas investments, for example.
3) You can make money *investing* in bitcoin companies.

The way I think of bitcoin, it's a tool like an iPhone. iPhones are *terrible* investments, but Apple Computers is a pretty decent one.

One other way I think of bitcoin is that it's like gold or oil. You generally don't want to *invest* in gold or oil.

I have a very small amount of my money in physical gold which I keep hidden in some safe location to deal with the possibility that we get invaded by space aliens or the zombie take over the world. If space aliens invade, most of my wealth is useless, but I have my bag of gold, which I consider more insurance than an investment. Once I'm covered for the 1% chance that the world will end, I invest the rest of my money for the 99% chance that it doesn't. (Part of the reason I think this way is having parents that lived through a civil war.)

If space aliens invade, then I don't want bitcoin, because computer networks would be rather useless.

answers.html:
It is not a wise or a unwise investment, because Bitcoin is not an investment. It was never intended to be one, and someone who tells you otherwise is either trying to fool you or has misunderstood the system.

What bitcoin is intended to be is a currency; I leave the question open about whether or not it meets the criteria for being one. One thing it certainly is is a payment system (a way to transfer value). So :

  • Since Bitcoin at least behaves in some ways like a currency, you can speculate on its exchange rates; it is quite risky and not the same as an investment.
  • Since Bitcoin is a payment system and a technological infrastructure, some people have build businesses around it (exchanges, mines, marketplaces, financial services, various other startups, etc.) and you can invest in those Bitcoin-based business. It would be the closest thing to "investing in Bitcoin" (because sure, the more Bitcoin in general succeeds, the more those businesses are likely to grow and if Bitcoin somehow completely fail, those business will fail too) but in the end it is simply investing in a business that happens to deal with Bitcoin. Those businesses can fail or succeed for the same reasons as any other business, independantly of Bitcoin's success in general.
  • Since Bitcoin is a payment system, you can also use it to buy various things, including investment products (some of them which are by themselves linked to the Bitcoin economy or technology, others that are not, but regardless of that this is not "investing is Bitcoin" it is "using Bitcoin to invest in something").

But no, there is no such thing as "investing in bitcoin".

Bitcoin, the largest cryptocurrency by market value, hit an all-time high of $69000 in October 2021 and is currently trading at $47000. The price of Bitcoin has over the years only shot up!

But before investing in bitcoin or any other cryptocurrency, for the time being, it’s important to step back from the FOMO, noise, excitement and first understand what it means to invest in a digital asset like cryptocurrency. To understand the implications of it you should ask yourself these questions!

Why am I investing?

The primary question is why you want to invest in the first place.

If you’re just afraid of missing out, then you should probably pause before moving forward. It’s important to truly understand bitcoin, cryptocurrency, or any asset before investing in it.

You should learn about the origin, concept, and how Blockchain Technology and Cryptocurrency works. ’Educate before allocate’ is a famous phrase said by Boneparth, who has invested in bitcoin since 2014.

What Is Cryptocurrency?

Cryptocurrencies are digital assets people use as investments and for online purchases. You exchange real currency, like dollars, to buy “coins” or “tokens” of a certain kind of cryptocurrency.

We value dollars and euros because we know we can purchase goods or services with them. The same goes for cryptocurrency. You exchange your money for crypto and use it just like real money (at places that accept it as a type of payment).

You’ve probably heard of people making (or losing!) hundreds of thousands of dollars by investing in cryptocurrency. It feels like a modern-day gold rush all of a sudden.

How Does Cryptocurrency Work?

Cryptocurrency is exchanged from person to person on the web without a middleman, like a bank or government. They’re decentralized which means no government or bank controls how they’re made, what their value is because of that, cryptocurrencies are worth whatever people are willing to pay or exchange for them.s, or how they’re exchanged.

Cryptocurrencies use something called blockchain technology. A blockchain is like a long receipt that keeps growing with each exchange of crypto. It’s a public record of all of the transactions that have ever happened in a given cryptocurrency.

Am I happy with the volatility?

Next, consider how well you handle extreme swings in price since bitcoin is a volatile asset. It’s not easy to handle for most investors who have only invested in Stock Markets over the years.

For some people, the volatility “may be OK, that may coincide with your appetite for rand your own risk tolerance and investment time horizon,” But, you still got to live with it.”

But regardless of your tolerance level, various experts warn that the volatility makes bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies a riskier investment than something like a low-cost index fund, which should be kept in mind.

How much can I afford to allocate?

Once you understand how much volatility you can stomach, you can determine how much money you can afford to invest. “Be very careful about how much you allocate and understand what you can tolerate because if you have invested all your money in Bitcoin and its price goes down by half, you would feel broke. Depending on what you can afford, a smaller allocation in bitcoin can hedge for any potential downturns in the market.

Diversification

Don’t put all your eggs in one basket is a famous phrase. Take note of it and invest wisely. It can be in the form of a monthly SIP wherein you won’t try to time the market and leave it for some time to witness the magic of compounding.

What’s your time horizon?

Bitcoin, as the most widely known cryptocurrency, benefits from the network effect - more people want to own Bitcoin because Bitcoin is owned by most people. Bitcoin is currently viewed by many investors as "digital gold," but it could also be used as a digital form of cash.

Investors in bitcoin believe the cryptocurrency will gain value over the long term because the supply is fixed, unlike the supplies of fiat currencies such as the U.S. dollar or the Japanese yen. The supply of Bitcoin is capped at just under 21 million coins, while central-bank-controlled currencies can be printed at the will of politicians. Many investors expect Bitcoin to gain value as fiat currencies depreciate.

The wealth is in holding the coins not trading and you must have heard the favorite word of every Crypto holder “HODL”.

Let us make it simple for you to decide —

Investing in cryptocurrency is a good way to build wealth for your future as the adoption of Blockchain technology is increasing. If you want a solid investment with diversification, don’t mess around by not adding crypto coins to your portfolio. But before that: pay out your debts, credit card bills and have an emergency fund that will cover three to six months of expenses.

Many people have been watching Bitcoin for years and wondering if it is still worth it and how to invest in bitcoin wisely and the price of Bitcoin is sky-rocketing. Also, if it's the rainy season you should carry your umbrella with you rather than be ignorant that it will not rain today. Think of it the same way as adoption and use cases of Cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin and Ethereum are increasing. You should make the right decision by not criticizing it but educating yourself about it.

In India, the concept of Bitcoin investment comes with little confusion. Most of them are not sure if bitcoin investment can be practiced freely, legally?

Well, the government has timely made efforts by reaching out to investors on this topic and told them about the latest amendment, and clear myth in the market (if any).

In order to put end to most of your basic doubts, let me update you with a report of 2018 disclosed by the former finance minister, late Mr. Arun Jaitley. He discussed Bitcoin and asked the Indians to stay away from crypto currencies. However, he added the government was open to the usage of Block chain technology which is the underlying technology for Bitcoins.

Later in the year 2020, over bitcoin investment, the RBI had officially stated that investors are free to invest in crypto currencies like Bitcoin and others. The government has always strived to ring-fence around regulated entities (includes capital market players like banks, insurers, brokers, DPs, investment managers, etc) from the associated risks like terror financing and money laundering through crypto currencies.

According to the experts of bitcoin currency, the investment is quite safe as they are not correlated to stock markets.

On the other hand, it involves risk as it does not qualify to be a currency. You may be aware that bitcoin is not a real currency but a crypto currency or digital currency but not backed by the central government. Hence, this investment is also known as gambling, not an investment option.

Thus, if you are planning to invest in bitcoin or any crypto transactions manage it with a lot of caution. Invest not more than 1/4th of your investment money in it. You can start investing by installing the bitcoin wallet. There you can get your account ready with crypto currency exchanges.

Source- Finladder

Don’t invest if you don’t understand
Some global bankers and experts have warned investors against investing in cryptocurrencies, because they are of the opinion that it is nothing but a bubble that is just about ready to burst. Jamie Dimon, CEO, JP Morgan, for instance, has recently expressed his doubts about the value of bitcoins, saying “It’s worse than tulip bulbs. It won’t end well. Someone is going to get killed.” However, owners and operators of bitcoin exchanges are of an entirely different opinion. Sandeep Goenka, Co- Founder and COO, Zebpay, says, “The comment from JP Morgan’s CEO was his personal view, and there is a possibility that he doesn’t understand the evolution of bitcoins. On the other hand, we have former Citigroup CEO Vikram Pandit investing in bitcoins.”

The problem is apparent: If global bankers don’t understand the phenomenon, retail investors might not have much of a chance either. So what should you do? Follow the simple yet profound wisdom of Warren Buffett—if you don’t understand it, don’t invest in it.

Whether to invest in Bitcoin in 2019 is a hot topic; all the noise surrounding cryptocurrencies could easily cloud your judgment on whether to try this lucrative digital asset. Being such a young asset, the market is volatile, filled with stories of extreme success or a massive failure. The issue at hand, therefore, is about making an educated decision based on timing, probability and whether the investment profile fits you.

Thinking about cryptocurrency investment for the first time may look like such a daunting prospect, especially in the absence of investment advice. The good news is that times have changed now and there is more information than you might consume and there are fewer entry barriers than before.

For instance, Coinbase, the leading digital wallet, has over 10 million investors who can buy Bitcoin, Ethereum, Litecoin and Bitcoin Cash at the snap of a finger.

There are many market investment funds that give potential investors easy access to different cryptocurrencies. There has never been a time when investing in cryptocurrencies was so straightforward for anyone who didn’t know where to start.

Bitcoin has definitely dominated the cryptocurrency market for about a decade now and it’s probably why it’s the most recognized digital asset. However, while perhaps the time to invest and reap large from Bitcoin could be slowly passing (those who invested earlier reaped mouthwatering returns), it doesn’t mean it is the only or best crypto investment opportunity today.

Blockchain technology may be the backbone of cryptocurrencies but there is much more to the technology than digital assets. The blockchain is revolutionizing every other industry from accounting, supply chain management, insurance, baking, and healthcare, voting systems, medicine, production lines and many others behind the scenes.

Yes.

At the current valuation, the Bitcoin is worth approximately ~$7 Billion. That is a very low figure for such a revolutionary technology.

Joseph Wang says that it's a terrible investment, but a good device for transmitting value. That doesn't make any sense.

Consider just one industry, remittances. 10's of billions of dollars a year are spent in fees each year. That is a massive sum. If Bitcoin just nibbled at that problem, it's valuation would be justifiably much larger than in its current state.

And there are many other areas as well in which Bitcoin may, very likely, play a major role. The potential upside is very large. The risks, in my opinion, are exaggerated. People don't like extreme novelty because they don't have prior examples to turn to, and that makes them uncomfortable.

Philosophical arguments aside, a sound investment is a profitable one. The risk/reward calculus for Bitcoin is very positive.

World Trade War

World War 3 is not being fought with conventional weapons. It’s being fought with toxic derivatives and 0% interest rate loans.
It’s being fought right now, all around you.

The nature of non conventional weapons makes them difficult to apprehend, much less understand, but they’re quite real nonetheless.
The effects are obvious, but the weapons themselves are invisible to the eye.
The banks have an undeclared war raging against the world and they won't stop until the world is in small easily digestible pieces.

It’s about survival at this point. If you are going to survive, you're going to have to be smart.

Central bank interest rates at near 0% worldwide and even negative in Sweden (-0.50) and Switzerland (-0.75)
Money deposited in the bank doesn't even pace inflation.

Pension funds, traditionally reliant on healthy interest rates are left with high risk investments.
Those investments haven't been successful… they’re losing money.

Investing in inflation proof assets like Picasso paintings, gold, etc. are effective if you have the capital to get into those high cost type of investments.

Remember, the world trade war continues, every country is trying to drive exports by devaluing their own currency.
Ok for corporate entities, in the short term, but devastating to individuals.

In the World Trade War , with every country trying to drive exports by devaluing their own currency, having an inflation proof asset is priceless.

Outside of the banking cartels, Bitcoin already is the de facto world reserve currency.
One million per Bitcoin may seem absurdly conservative and having that kind of value is essential to surviving hyperinflation.

We can look back in history to see the effects of this game in Weimar Germany; nearly identical timeline. Wheelbarrows to carry enough cash to buy a loaf of bread.

More contemporarily we have only to look at Venezuela.
The only bulwark stopping mass starvation, is Bitcoin.

Yes, Bitcoin, saving the world.

Yes, if you are good at buying winning lottery tickets, then you should buy Bitcoin. Buy when the price is low, and sell when the price is high.

You are not investing. You are gambling.

You are buying a collectible, like postage stamps or beanie babies. When you invest in a company, you expect the company to invest your capital, produce more, and turn a profit in terms of real wealth produced.

Bitcoins do not produce real wealth. There is only transfer of wealth from one fool to another. If you are the lucky fool, you will talk loudly about your brilliance in “investing” in Bitcoin. If you are the unlucky fool, you will not talk. As there is no real wealth created, the number of lucky and unlucky fools are exactly equal.

Do not be distracted by the arguments about technological magic fairy dust, that somehow gives Bitcoin value. The “blockchain” is like putting four wheels on cars - a good idea, but not something you can own. Buying a car is not an investment in four-wheel technology, just as buying Bitcoin is not an investment in blockchain technology.

The real way to make money off Bitcoin (other then supernatural luck) is to become an exchange. You do not want to hold the stuff. You want to collect a percentage off the transaction in Bitcoin between fools.

As an exchange, you then want to write breathless promotional articles describing how Bitcoin is the next new thing to make fools rich. Be sure that links to your exchange are well presented.

You do have to be a bit careful, as some of the folk moving money through your exchange are doing so in violation of local laws. Eventually local enforcement will get wise, and you want to be protected in the case.

Whether you decide to invest in stocks or Cryptocurrency (Bitcoin) you should prepare yourself for a certain amount of volatility.

Bitcoin does seem to attract more media attention than the stock market when there is a move in price.

You can invest in many other things besides cryptocurrencies, but why Bitcoin is still attractive? Why people still invest in Bitcoin?

1. The volatility of Bitcoin can be a good basis for trading. Buying it low and selling it high can bring you some profit. You can trade it frequently or you might opt to buy Bitcoin when the price lands on the hypothetical bottom, and sell it at the high price much later.

2. The other reason to invest in Bitcoin is the support of this relatively new technology that changes the reality we live in gradually. As the blockchain technology becomes more and more significant in the modern world, Bitcoin keeps its domination of the cryptocurrency market and still can be considered as an important asset in the world of blockchain-based projects. Bitcoin can be a gate for the altcoins that you will probably need to use dApps and other services accepting cryptocurrencies.

3. Finally, you never know when you will need to make an anonymous international transaction of a huge amount of money. When the banks can create some obstacles for the money senders, the Bitcoin network operates 24/7 and require nothing but the keys pair and the relevant address in the system.

There are many Bitcoin supporters who believe that digital currency is the future. However, Bitcoin was not designed as a normal equity investment (no shares have been issued).

If you really want to profit from Bitcoin, I suggest that you shouldn’t take the decision of investing or not investing in Bitcoin before understanding it completely.

After that, I will give you my perspective about whether you should invest.

Please go through these 4 pics by PwC, Business Today, and WhatisBitcoin to understand the basic theory of Bitcoin:

I assume you have understood the basics of Cryptocurrency, Blockchain on which Cryptocurrency works, what Bitcoin is, and how you use Bitcoin.

Here is why Bitcoin might go on to be much bigger, and might still be the NEXT big thing:

  • When using Cryptocurrency, consumers benefit from a wider selection of merchants both domestic and international without worrying about exchange fees.
  • The details of their transactions are encrypted, which protects their personal data.
  • The pandemic has also seemed to accelerate the widespread adoption of blockchain technology, as more and more businesses, payments companies and e-commerce marketplaces turn to digital currencies, especially stablecoins.
  • There are many Bitcoin supporters who believe that digital currency is the future.
  • Recently bitcoin seems to have assumed the role of investment asset, as traders, institutional investors and small savers have woken up to the potential gains from price appreciation.
  • In some parts of the world, bitcoin is still a more efficient and cheaper way to transfer money across borders, and several remittance startups make use of this feature.

Whenever there is news like this one (this one by Statista):

Interest in Bitcoin goes up like this:

Speculative investors were drawn to digital money after it appreciated rapidly in May 2011 and again in November 2013. This, is their primary argument, as summarized by Unchained Capital:

Bitcoin risks:

  • A number of large and small retailers accept the cryptocurrency as a form of payment, although reports suggest that demand for this function is not high. If fewer people begin to accept Bitcoin as a currency, these digital units may lose value and could become worthless.
  • The improvement in domestic payment methods and the rapid development of alternative (non-cryptocurrency) forms of international transfers, however, has reduced bitcoin’s advantage in this area, especially given its increasing fees and frequent network bottlenecks.
  • Bitcoin’s cost and speed advantages are being eroded as traditional channels improve and the network’s fees continue to increase and availability remains a problem in many countries.
  • Security risk:
    If a thief gains access to a Bitcoin owner's computer hard drive and steals his private encryption key, he could transfer the stolen Bitcoins to another account.
    This is particularly problematic once you remember that all Bitcoin transactions are permanent and irreversible. It's like dealing with cash. There is no third party or a payment processor, as in the case of a debit or credit card – hence, no source of protection or appeal if there is a problem.
  • Market risk:
    Like with any investment, Bitcoin values can fluctuate. Indeed, the value of the currency has seen wild swings in price over its short existence.
  • Regulatory risk:
    Furthermore, the increasing oversight and regulation to prevent money laundering and illegal transactions have restricted the cryptocurrency’s use for privacy reasons.

Conclusion:
Money you put in banks or FDs is used to give loans.
Money you put in the stock market helps the economy grow.
The only use of Bitcoin is as an alternate currency. Which implies, that for it to become actually useful, all fiat currencies including the US Dollar, the Indian Rupee etc. will have to fall. I am not sure if that is practically possible.

Way too many people have made serious money from Bitcoin. And many many more probably will.
But it is impossible to tell till then this will last. Might last beyond our lifetimes, or might last 2 more years.

I suggest you put a little money in it that you won’t regret losing. It might make you rich. Or it might go down the drain. That is the only way to deal with risky investments.

Tesla CEO Elon Musk recently made headlines after announcing that his company bought $1.5 billion worth of Bitcoin.

While the cryptocurrency has been around for a long time, its value has increased by more than 370 % in the last year. Well before Tesla's investment in Bitcoin, Musk has been credited with driving up the price of cryptocurrencies by publicly endorsing them.

Because of its soaring price, Bitcoin may seem like an attractive investment. But is it the right time to buy?... ok before that let’s see

How Has The Bitcoin Price Performed?

The growth of Bitcoin as a popular commodity is largely due to its price fluctuations. Indeed, one of the main reasons Bitcoin has become such a popular investable phenomenon is the way its price has risen — especially since 2017, when it experienced its first parabolic movement.

With its returns, Bitcoin has proven to be the highest performing asset of the last decade — but it has been a bumpy path. The coin has reached a high of $60,000, but it was worth about $3,000 less a year ago.

The above price map, which shows the entire history of Bitcoin's price, demonstrates how well the coin has done. The coin's most recent all-time high, apparent at the end of 2017, has been dwarfed by the recent price surge towards the end of 2021.

This chart may also indicate that the price of Bitcoin appears to be topping out, indicating that a significant price drop is imminent. Although the coin's parabolic movement may necessitate a correction soon, there is a lot of evidence that Bitcoin's price will continue to grow today and through 2021.

Should You Invest In Bitcoin Right Now?

Many investors would be curious as to when the best time is to invest in Bitcoin. While it is difficult to predict when to enter the market, it is fair to assume that Bitcoin is currently a good investment due to the increasing levels of enthusiasm and adoption surrounding the coin.

For example, since the latter half of 2020, the CEO of MicroStrategy, a large computer company, has been continuously buying millions of dollars worth of Bitcoin. And more recently, CEO Michael Saylor added to his company's investment plan by purchasing another big chunk of Bitcoin.

Many other well-known investors and celebrities are currently investing in Bitcoin, including the world's richest man, Elon Musk. Bitcoin, according to Musk, is not only a safe investment now, but also has a significant role to play in the future of finance and investing.

Risk and Reward Analysis

While it would be tempting to invest a large sum of money in Bitcoin now in the hopes of seeing large returns in a few months or even years, this is not the case. It is important, as with any investment, to consider the risks and rewards.

As previously said, Bitcoin is highly volatile, which can be difficult for certain investors to deal with. Though it has been on a strong upward trajectory for many months, no one knows how long it will continue. In the past, the cryptocurrency has undergone wild price swings, losing up to 80% of its value.

Bitcoin, for example, soared from around $1,000 to more than $17,000 between 2017 and 2019, before plummeting to around $3,000.

Bitcoin is also not playing the true role in society that it was designed to play. Bitcoin was supposed to be the future of money and a revolutionary way to transact, but its ability to grow in price so quickly has ironically rendered it a bad transaction tool.

However, many of these issues will apply to a variety of assets or resources, so it's all about balancing the risk and reward for investing in such a young and developing commodity.

The Potential For Bitcoin Investors

Despite all that has been said about Bitcoin's danger, it still has a lot of opportunities for investors. Bitcoin has potential that few other assets can even come close to matching.

This can be seen by looking at Bitcoin over the last decade, as the price has risen from $1 in February 2011 to $55,000 ten years later.

All of this potential, though, is contingent on the position that Bitcoin will carve out for itself in the future. More use cases, adoption, and normalization of Bitcoin would result in ever-increasing prices.

“Cryptocurrencies could stay niche, become mainstream, disappear without trace, or something in between,” says Danny Cox of financial services firm Hargreaves Lansdown. “Any investment should be regarded as very high risk.”

Mark Hipperson, CEO of cryptocurrency platform Ziglu, also makes a case for digital coins becoming more popular.

“With more and more major brands embracing crypto, such as Tesla and Starbucks, [Starbucks is testing a way for users of its mobile app to pay for coffee and food with the cryptocurrency Bakkt Cash, for example], there now seems to be little chance that crypto will be accepted in as many places as conventional currencies one day soon.”

Is There A Less Risky Way Of Investing In Bitcoin?

In terms of opportunity, Bitcoin investing is a one-way street, and due to the high degree of volatility in the market, there will be periods when your investment will be hemorrhaging money and leading to large losses.

Trading, on the other hand, gives you much more leverage over your assets because you can respond to the market and avoid losses before they become an issue. Trading also provides a variety of tools and strategies, such as shorting that enable you to benefit regardless of market fluctuations.

Shorting allows you to bet against the market and make money if the price of Bitcoin falls, reducing the chance of losing money in a general market decline. Trading also helps you to use leverage, which is another asset that can help you significantly boost your earnings.

In Bitcoin, leverage refers to borrowing money from a platform in order to increase the size of your trades and hence your future profit returns. This is also a less risky strategy because you don't have to put as much money into a transaction to make it profitable.

Final Word

Bitcoin is perhaps one of the most talked-about currencies, but it is also one of the least invested in. The coin has a lot of potential and excitement for the future, but many people are either uncertain or uninformed about it.

However, by 2021, the concept of investing in Bitcoin will have become more mainstream, thanks to the efforts of people like Michael Saylor and Elon Musk, who are encouraging others to do so. It may be a very different asset from what investors are used to seeing, but it also provides a lot more than conventional assets.

While the cryptocurrency has been around for a long time, its value has increased by more than 370 % in the last year. Well before Tesla's investment in Bitcoin, Musk has been credited with driving up the price of cryptocurrencies by publicly endorsing them.
Because of its soaring price, Bitcoin may seem like an attractive investment. But is it the right time to buy?... ok before that let’s see
How Has The Bitcoin Price Performed?

The growth of Bitcoin as a popular commodity is largely due to its price fluctuations. Indeed, one of the main reasons Bitcoin has become such a popular investable phenomenon is the way its price has risen — especially since 2017, when it experienced its first parabolic movement.

With its returns, Bitcoin has proven to be the highest performing asset of the last decade — but it has been a bumpy path. The coin has reached a high of $60,000, but it was worth about $3,000 less a year ago.

The above price map, which shows the entire history of Bitcoin's price, demonstrates how well the coin has done. The coin's most recent all-time high, apparent at the end of 2017, has been dwarfed by the recent price surge towards the end of 2021.

This chart may also indicate that the price of Bitcoin appears to be topping out, indicating that a significant price drop is imminent. Although the coin's parabolic movement may necessitate a correction soon, there is a lot of evidence that Bitcoin's price will continue to grow today and through 2021.
Should You Invest In Bitcoin Right Now?

Many investors would be curious as to when the best time is to invest in Bitcoin. While it is difficult to predict when to enter the market, it is fair to assume that Bitcoin is currently a good investment due to the increasing levels of enthusiasm and adoption surrounding the coin.

For example, since the latter half of 2020, the CEO of MicroStrategy, a large computer company, has been continuously buying millions of dollars worth of Bitcoin. And more recently, CEO Michael Saylor added to his company's investment plan by purchasing another big chunk of Bitcoin.

Many other well-known investors and celebrities are currently investing in Bitcoin, including the world's richest man, Elon Musk. Bitcoin, according to Musk, is not only a safe investment now, but also has a significant role to play in the future of finance and investing.
Risk and Reward Analysis

While it would be tempting to invest a large sum of money in Bitcoin now in the hopes of seeing large returns in a few months or even years, this is not the case. It is important, as with any investment, to consider the risks and rewards.

As previously said, Bitcoin is highly volatile, which can be difficult for certain investors to deal with. Though it has been on a strong upward trajectory for many months, no one knows how long it will continue. In the past, the cryptocurrency has undergone wild price swings, losing up to 80% of its value.
Bitcoin, for example, soared from around $1,000 to more than $17,000 between 2017 and 2019, before plummeting to around $3,000.

Bitcoin is also not playing the true role in society that it was designed to play. Bitcoin was supposed to be the future of money and a revolutionary way to transact, but its ability to grow in price so quickly has ironically rendered it a bad transaction tool.
However, many of these issues will apply to a variety of assets or resources, so it's all about balancing the risk and reward for investing in such a young and developing commodity.
The Potential For Bitcoin Investors
Despite all that has been said about Bitcoin's danger, it still has a lot of opportunities for investors. Bitcoin has potential that few other assets can even come close to matching.
This can be seen by looking at Bitcoin over the last decade, as the price has risen from $1 in February 2011 to $55,000 ten years later.

All of this potential, though, is contingent on the position that Bitcoin will carve out for itself in the future. More use cases, adoption, and normalization of Bitcoin would result in ever-increasing prices.

“Cryptocurrencies could stay niche, become mainstream, disappear without trace, or something in between,” says Danny Cox of financial services firm Hargreaves Lansdown. “Any investment should be regarded as very high risk.”
Mark Hipperson, CEO of cryptocurrency platform Ziglu, also makes a case for digital coins becoming more popular.

“With more and more major brands embracing crypto, such as Tesla and Starbucks, [Starbucks is testing a way for users of its mobile app to pay for coffee and food with the cryptocurrency Bakkt Cash, for example], there now seems to be little chance that crypto will be accepted in as many places as conventional currencies one day soon.”
Is There A Less Risky Way Of Investing In Bitcoin?

In terms of opportunity, Bitcoin investing is a one-way street, and due to the high degree of volatility in the market, there will be periods when your investment will be hemorrhaging money and leading to large losses.

Trading, on the other hand, gives you much more leverage over your assets because you can respond to the market and avoid losses before they become an issue. Trading also provides a variety of tools and strategies, such as shorting that enable you to benefit regardless of market fluctuations.

Shorting allows you to bet against the market and make money if the price of Bitcoin falls, reducing the chance of losing money in a general market decline. Trading also helps you to use leverage, which is another asset that can help you significantly boost your earnings.

In Bitcoin, leverage refers to borrowing money from a platform in order to increase the size of your trades and hence your future profit returns. This is also a less risky strategy because you don't have to put as much money into a transaction to make it profitable.

At various times in history, feathers have been money, shells have been money, dollars and euros are money. Gold and silver are certainly money. Bitcoin and other crypto-currencies can also be money.

People say some forms of money, such as Bitcoin or U.S. dollars, are not backed by anything.

But that’s not true. They are backed by one thing: confidence. If you and I have confidence that something is money and we agree that it’s money, then it’s money. I can call something money, but if nobody else in the world wants it, then it’s not money. The same applies to gold, dollars and crypto-currencies.

Governments have an edge here because they make you pay taxes in their money. Put another way, governments essentially create an artificial use case for their own forms of paper money by threatening people with punishment if they do not pay taxes denominated in the government’s own fiat currency. The dollar has a monopoly as legal tender for the payment of U.S. taxes.

According to John Maynard Keynes and many other economists, it is that ability of state power to coerce tax payments in a specified currency that gives a currency its intrinsic value. This theory of money boils down to saying we value dollars only because we must use them to pay our taxes — otherwise we go to jail.

So-called crypto-currencies such as Bitcoin have two main features in common. The first is that they are not issued or regulated by any central bank or single regulatory authority. They are created in accordance with certain computer algorithms and are issued and transferred through a distributed processing network using open source code.

The bitcoin market is a bubble. Like all bubbles, it will eventually pop. And like everyone who's ever been screwed by a bubble, the people investing in bitcoins now think that they will get out of the market before the bubble pops. Unfortunately, someone has to be holding those bitcoins when prices collapse. There's an old saying about investing in bubbles: it's like picking up pennies in front of a steam roller.

If you don't believe that the bitcoin market is a bubble, let me justify myself. Bitcoins basically combine the two worst parts of the two different types of stores of value: gold (or gold-backed currency) and fiat currency. Bitcoins have no intrinsic value or industrial applications or even physical presence, so they are unlike gold in that respect. They also have no central bank backing them, so they are unlike fiat currencies in that respect. Basically, bitcoins obtain their value because people buying them believe they can sell them at a profit later (or, ostensibly, because they believe they can exchange them for goods. It is a currency after all).

Here's where the issue comes into play: bitcoins can't function as a currency in the current environment. You want a currency to be stable in value relative to other currencies. It really helps when it comes to doing business and planning expenditures. Bitcoins are constantly increasing in value. This means that if you want to buy a new computer using bitcoins, it will make more sense to wait, since your bitcoins will gain value the longer you hold them. But that logic means you will never spend your bitcoins, or at the very least you will put off spending them as long as possible. This means that very few people will be spending bitcoins as currency, and the demand for them as currency will be very low.

But if that's the case, why has the value of bitcoins been skyrocketing? It's because of speculators inflating the bubble. And the bubble will pop. Maybe then bitcoins can be used as a currency. But as of right now, investing in bitcoins is just like picking up pennies in front of a steam roller...

I first discovered bitcoin while browsing reddit a few years ago during the June of 2011 bubble. At the time a single bitcoin’s market value was a record $30 and the currency’s users were ecstatic. For whatever reason I passed it off as a fad and the following days of the price falling only reassured me that it was. Fast forward a couple years to early 2013 and another bitcoin article pops up on reddit. Bitcoin had set a new all time high and was still on the rise. The new decentralized crypto-currency caught my interest again and this time I seriously considered investing. After doing some research I became infatuated with bitcoin. This was not just because it has the potential to increase my personal wealth but because the technology has the potential to change the world. As bitcoin is still in its early stages, the price isn't as important as the protocol itself and the work being put into making it more valuable.

As with any investment, it is important to understand what you are investing in before you put money into it. This is what makes bitcoin so tricky. Its technological complexities are understood by few outside of the computer science world. It is for this reason that Warren Buffet wont touch it with a ten foot pole- he simply doesn't understand it. In the same way that most people do not understand how the internet works, most people do not understand how bitcoin works.This lack of understanding scares off many new potential investors and is a major impediment to bitcoin’s growth. However those who dig deeper into what bitcoin is can gain a solid understanding of its features after reading a few short articles. Only once you know how bitcoin and its ecosystem works can you do a thorough advantage-disadvantage analysis and determine whether or not it is better than its competitor, fiat currency.

So what are the advantages of bitcoin?

As a mean of exchange, bitcoin is far superior to other currencies. Bitcoin can be transferred between any two people on the planet with internet access for a very small fee or no fee at all. Because there is no centralized third party needed to verify transactions, there is no need to pay for something such as a wiring fee or credit card fee. For the first time in history somebody can transfer massive amounts of monetary value across the world for free. The global and frictionless nature of bitcoin also allows underbanked people living in developing countries to access a global bitcoin economy. In a world where more people have internet connected telephones than toilets, bitcoin can serve as a revolutionary facilitator of global commerce and trade.
Bitcoins are very secure. A well secured bitcoin wallet is much harder to break into than a bank. Bitcoin also beats out credit cards on this front as when you make a bitcoin transaction you don't give the merchant the information needed to charge you extra. When Target was hacked, millions of credit card numbers were stolen and subject to fraud. This could not happen with bitcoin.
Bitcoin transactions are very transparent. Although you might not know who is sending who money, the block chain provides a public ledger of every bitcoin transaction that has ever taken place. This allows regulators to track any illicit activity in a way that is not possible with cash.
Because there is a finite supply of bitcoin, the rate of inflation is predetermined and easily trackable. This is a huge plus for people that live in countries such as Argentina and Zimbabwe where their government’s overzealous printing of money has devalued their currencies.
The bitcoin protocol cannot be manipulated by any single entity. There is no person or group of people that can change the way bitcoin operates. Think of it as a bank that is run by non-discriminatory and infallible math instead of people. Entities such as paypal and various banks have been known to block transactions to certain people or groups that they deem unfit. With bitcoin you can give money to whoever you want, wherever they are, whenever you want.

It is just as important to understand the disadvantages of bitcoin before making an investment decision. So what are its drawbacks?

Bitcoin’s price volatility has made it a somewhat unstable store of value. Bitcoin’s value has been known to play chutes and ladders. It can gain or lose value of more than 20% in a day. A merchant might sell one of their products for 1 bitcoin on Monday and that bitcoin might be worth 20% less by Wednesday.
Exchanges have been known to be sketchy and fraudulent. Mt. Gox, once the largest bitcoin exchange on the planet, recently declared bankruptcy and disappeared with hundreds of millions of dollars worth of bitcoin.

answers.html:
Is It Viable to buy bitcoins right now? What is my opinion?

Overall, we think – YES, you should buy bitcoins and use them as a way to diversify your investment strategy. The common sense tells us that we shouldn’t put all eggs in one basket, so bitcoin — and other cryptocurrencies for that matter — is one of the baskets to think about, and it is arguably the most potent basket to anyone’s portfolio. Let’s look at a few reasons why that’s the case.

Now, How to buy Bitcoins?

You can Buy Bitcoin using CEX.io which is a great place to BUY/SELL bitcoin

(Supports any debit/credit card, Bank Transfer etc. )

To Buy Bitcoin using Paypal you may choose, LocalBitcoins which is super fast, Peer-to-peer bitcoin trading website. But to secure your money and bitcoin just verify your mobile, turn on two factor authentication via Google Authenticator APP and you can buy Bitcoins within an hour. It has escrow service so rest assured your money is safe.)

1. Bitcoin has a solid tech foundation
It is decentralized, backed by the rock-solid blockchain technology. You can can’t just invent more bitcoins — its protocol is set to automatically half the volume of bitcoins that can be mined every four years. So while there will be new bitcoins on the market, there won’t be a ton of them, making sure that the law of supply and demand keeps ticking to the benefit of bitcoin owners.

2. Bitcoin has been around since 2009
It is not invented yesterday, and we had almost a decade to play with it. The underlying technology (blockchain) has proven its worth and is now used by major corporations. So there is value behind bitcoin, and again — other cryptocurrencies. Speaking of which, the newer cryptocurrencies are also made on solid foundations though they tend to be more volatile than bitcoin.

3. Bitcoin is the digital gold standard
As noted, Bitcoin is the longest running cryptocurrency and is considered the digital gold standard. This in turn makes it a safe haven when economic challenges struck; for instance, bitcoin was up 15 percent on the news of Brexit. And with general economic uncertainty, its role as a safe haven will become increasingly important.

4. Bitcoin is the reserve currency of the cryptocurrency space
Think of it as a U.S. dollar of cryptocurrencies. You can use it to buy into Ethereum and Litecoin markets; when there is an ICO (Initial Coin Offering) — which is the IPO (Initial Public Offering) for cryptocurrencies — you typically need bitcoins to buy in. Also, bitcoin is by far the most accepted cryptocurrency in the world.

5. Bitcoin is already mainstream
Related to the previous point… While less-known cryptocurrencies have to fight for wider adoption, bitcoin is already accepted at hundreds of thousands of merchants and vendors around the world. In fact, there are already more than a thousand bitcoin ATMs all around the world, with new ATMs being added every single day!

6. Major corporations are on board, as well
Aside from small and medium sized businesses, major corporations also allow users to pay with bitcoins, including Microsoft, Dell, Expedia, Time Inc, and many others. And it was back in 2013 when Bank of America Merrill Lynch stated its belief that “bitcoin can become a major means of payment for e-commerce and may emerge as a serious competitor to traditional money-transfer providers.”

7. China is getting in…
Yes, the country has tried and still tries to regulate bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies, and even ban them, but around 80 percent of new bitcoins are mined and almost three quarters are traded there. So while the government doesn’t like the money it can’t regulate, its rising middle class can’t get enough of it. And the same (obviously) goes for the country’s super-rich.

Conclusion

Yes, we think it is still a good idea to invest in Bitcoins. There are many places around the web from where you can buy bitcoins

answers.html: At what price should you invest in Bitcoin? At what price should you invest in Apple shares? At what price should you invest in real estate? Investment is a personal decision based on risk how risk averse you are. Bitcoin at $200 looked expensive. At $2000 looked expensive. Who is to say at $200,000 it won’t still look expensive? You are going to receive answers to this that range greatly from opinion to opinion. I will give you my 2 cents on the subject.

If you asked, most people in 1973 would not have told you it was a good idea to invest in cellphones, but they would have been very wrong. They would have said this because the idea was too abstract for them to accept as becoming reality.

This is the case with cryptocurrency and even though bitcoin is facing some criticism right now because of the high transaction times and fees, it will survive the test of time because it has become a store of value. Once some of the altcoins become more prevalent the activity on the bitcoin blockchain will slow down and the economy surrounding it will stabilize.

That being said, Yes, you should invest in bitcoin. Though, in my opinion there is more room for growth at this moment in some of the altcoins like Litecoin, Ethereum, Iota, Ripple, & Tron.

Only 24 percent of Americans are familiar with Bitcoin. Here's what you need to know about this “cryptocurrency.”

How’s this for a hero’s journey: In July 2010, one Bitcoin cost just 5 cents. In December 2017, that figure rose to nearly $20,000. And within the last 24 hours, the price fell below $8,000 — and the global cryptocurrency market lost more than $100 billion.

If you’ve heard Bitcoin as a buzzword but are at a loss when it comes to the definition, you’re not alone. Just 24 percent of U.S. adults are familiar with Bitcoin — but that hasn’t stopped the digital currency’s circulation value from swelling to more than $152 billion despite the recent downturn. That's like a Powerball jackpot on steroids — and a big reason Bitcoin has been such a hot topic recently. Whether you want to be able to talk intelligently about it at a cocktail party or are seriously considering putting some money into it, here's what you need to know.

Think about digital currencies like viewing your checking account balance online — you see the number on your screen, but you don’t have the bills in your hands.

WHAT IS BITCOIN?

Bitcoin is one type of digital currency (or “cryptocurrency”), dreamed up by an anonymous inventor in the wake of the 2008 financial crisis. Think about digital currencies like viewing your checking account balance online — you see the number on your screen, but you don’t have the bills in your hands. In the case of Bitcoin and other digital currencies, however, there is no standardized physical representation (like a dollar bill) — the assets exist only in digital form. There's also no regulation. The payment network that allows the digital tokens to move between individuals isn’t managed by any one entity (like the government) or company (like Visa, Wells Fargo or Venmo). Instead, it’s decentralized, made possible by a system of computers around the world. You can't use it for many purchases. Some large retailers like Overstock and Expedia have made headlines by starting to accept it, but they're outliers. And transactions are private; in fact, many users value the degree of anonymity that digital currencies offer.

HOW DOES BITCOIN WORK?

The technology that makes Bitcoin and other digital currencies work is called blockchain, which Mercina Tillemann, chief operating officer at the Global Blockchain Business Council, says is kind of like a set of railroad tracks. "In order for me to get something from me to anywhere else, I need that framework — [those tracks] — to exist.” Bitcoin is like a train car that travels on top of the tracks. When you send Bitcoin to someone, the transaction is verified by computers all over the world. The computer or data center that verifies the transaction first (it involves solving a complex mathematical equation) is rewarded in the form of a Bitcoin payment, says Kyle Forkey, general partner at Amentum, a cryptocurrency investment firm. (People and groups who race to do this can turn a significant profit.)

Until recently, it was difficult to move something digitally without the risk of it being copied or altered in the process. For example, think about when you send someone an email — you retain the original, and they receive a copy. If the same thing happened when you sent money, it’d be a real problem, says Tilleman. That’s why we currently rely on intermediaries — banks, credit unions, companies like PayPal — to make sure that doubling-up issue never occurs. These middlemen charge fees for ensuring that when you send someone money, you’re parting ways with it completely, and the other person is legitimately receiving it. With Bitcoin, there's also always an intermediary — it's whoever is managing the transaction, whether an exchange or other platform. But because there are no restrictions on who can participate (and no account minimums), they're not the traditional financial services players.

SHOULD YOU INVEST IN BITCOIN?

Before diving into Bitcoin or other digital currencies, you need to understand the risks. One: volatility. It's normal in the world of cryptocurrencies for prices to go up and down 30 percent in a single day, says Bobby Ong, co-founder of CoinGecko, a cryptocurrency valuation and ranking website. Two: The fuzzy future. “I do fundamentally believe that blockchain technology will ultimately change the way money moves from one place to another,” says David Bach, author of "Smart Couples Finish Rich," on a recent episode of my HerMoney Podcast. But he also thinks that “90 percent of the cryptocurrencies out there will be worthless within less than five years.”

That means only investing as much as you’re comfortable losing, which Bach says should be no more than 1 to 2 percent of your overall portfolio. If you decide to go forward, dollar-cost averaging could be a good way to do it, since each prices vary widely from day to day. (How? Take the amount of money you decided to put in, then divide it by 12. On the first of every month for a year, buy that amount of your chosen currency.) Two top digital currencies are currently Bitcoin and Ethereum, so Ong says he’d likely look at those first, putting 70 to 80 percent of his portfolio in those two coins, then invest the remaining 20 to 30 percent in smaller cryptocurrencies. Diversity in this sector is as important as it is in the markets overall.

HOW DO YOU GO ABOUT IT?

If you’re looking for an easy way to buy Bitcoin or another digital currency, there are user-friendly exchange services that allow you to use money in your bank account to make the purchase. “Coinbase is kind of the gold standard, but there are a lot of other really great exchanges that offer a wider range of currencies,” says Tilleman. You create an account, input the account information you’d like to use, then make your purchase. Know that if you do use an exchange, just like transferring to any currency, you will be charged a transaction fee — for example, Coinbase’s averages 1.49 percent for Bitcoin, says Dan Romero, vice president and general manager of Coinbase.

Since Bitcoin isn’t controlled by any one entity, if your coins are stolen by a hacker, they’re likely gone forever.

Finally, let's talk about security risk here — and the extra steps you need to take to keep your assets safe. When you buy stocks, a registry is kept of all the shareholders. But since Bitcoin isn’t controlled by any one entity, if your coins are stolen by a hacker, they’re likely gone forever. “Whoever has it owns it,” says Ong.

Once you buy units of a digital currency, they’re kept in your digital wallet, which can be easily stored on the exchange you purchased it on. The site gives you a unique key (a string of letters and numbers) to use for access. But keeping your Bitcoin in the exchange-provided digital wallet might not be the most secure option — for example, in late January, hackers stole upwards of $500 million in digital currency when they broke into an exchange called Coincheck. You can read the fine print on an exchange’s security policy to see if they offer insurance, but that’s rare — most insurance companies shy away from insuring digital currencies since it’s almost impossible to retrieve stolen coins. Instead, look into using a “hardware wallet” like Ledger or Trezor, says Ong. These cost less than $100 and are protected with a PIN and a backup called a "seed" in case you forget your PIN. Suffice it to say you'll have to make sure you keep this device as safe as possible. Ironically, the best place to do that might be an old fashioned safety deposit box at old fashioned institution called a bank.

The site gives you a unique key (a string of letters and numbers) to use for access. But keeping your Bitcoin in the exchange-provided digital wallet might not be the most secure option — for example, in late January, hackers stole upwards of $500 million in digital currency when they broke into an exchange called Coincheck. You can read the fine print on an exchange’s security policy to see if they offer insurance, but that’s rare — most insurance companies shy away from insuring digital currencies since it’s almost impossible to retrieve stolen coins. Instead, look into using a “hardware wallet” like Ledger or Trezor, says Ong. These cost less than $100 and are protected with a PIN and a backup called a "seed" in case you forget your PIN. Suffice it to say you'll have to make sure you keep this device as safe as possible. Ironically, the best place to do that might be an old fashioned safety deposit box at old fashioned institution called a bank.

Let’s make it more interesting by saying, **Yes**, you should invest in Bitcoin. It is definitely a good idea.

Needless to say, **Bitcoin** is the single best performing **asset** in the past decade. Recently when Morgan Creek Digital people opened a $1 million bet asking anyone in the world to challenge that Bitcoin will be outperformed by any other asset class.

It is no surprise that anyone hasn’t yet accepted the bet.

No one is betting against BTC.

Instead, Bitcoin in your portfolio is an agent of **de-riskification** if I would have to coin a word.

Bitcoin is a non-correlated, asymmetric return asset. By putting it in your portfolio, you can reduce the risk profile, increase sharpe ratio, and produce a material amount of impact on overall portfolio with a single digit allocation. Essentially, it improves your portfolio :)

The returns are so asymmetric that it can balance your portfolio in the maximum potential way !!

Asymmetric means if you allocate 1% to BTC and in 10 years this 1% might just simply outperform and become larger than everything you have invested in the rest 99% while, on the other hand, this 1% might just go to Zero.

However, the likely hood of going to Zero is negligible but cannot be denied because ultimately Bitcoin is software and softwares can have catastrophic bugs !!

But still, see this excellent example to understand the point of 1% allocation and asymmetricity that I am talking about.

Some numbers to ponder when thinking about value of adding #Bitcoin to your portfolio Endowments have $613B in Assets. Average return over past 5 yrs was mediocre 7.2% Had they allocated 1% to $BTC return would’ve been 9.2% Had #Bitcoin gone to zero, return would’ve been 7%

Furthermore, if Bitcoin survives which I believe is likely to, even 1% of your allocation of wealth can easily do 100–200x still at current prices.

The case for a small allocation to Bitcoin By Wences Casares, CEO of Xapo (a Bitcoin company) who makes a similar interesting case:

*“In my (subjective) opinion the chances of Bitcoin failing are at least 20%. But after 10 years of working well without interruption, with more than 60 million holders, adding more than 1 million new holders per month and moving more than $1 billion per day worldwide, it has a good chance of succeeding. In my (subjective) opinion those chances of succeeding are at least 50%. If Bitcoin does succeed, 1 Bitcoin may be worth more than $1 million in 7 to 10 years. That is 250 times what it is worth today (at the time of writing the price of Bitcoin is ~ $4,000).*

*I suggest that a $10 million portfolio should invest at most $100,000 in Bitcoin (up to 1% but not more as the risk of losing this investment is high). If Bitcoin fails, this portfolio will lose at most $100,000 or 1% of its value over 3 to 5 years, which most portfolios can bear. But if Bitcoin succeeds, in 7 to 10 years those $100,000 may be worth more than $25 million, more than twice the value of the entire initial portfolio”*

So by now you much have had the Gottcha feeling, if you haven’t still, I recommend you to pay attention to this graph, hahhahaha

The safe Haven of the COVID pandemic?

Let’s find out!

Cryptocurrency:The New Dawn

  1. Image source: Information age 

While the nations are slowly recovering from the economic slowdown due to the pandemic,with the stock market still under performing,Cryptocurrencies are becoming the new rage of the age.A cryptocurrency is a digital or virtual currency that is secured by cryptography, which makes it nearly impossible to counterfeit or double spend. In a nut shell it is a software program with a value pegged to it.

Instead of restraining us to Bitcoin let us have a look at the overall the potential of cryptocurrencies.

To set things into perspective,at the time of writing this article, the price of Ethereum,the hot cake of cryptocurrencies stands at $400 per coin,hitting a two year high.

Considering the price in January 2020, which was hovering around 100USD,that's a four fold increase.Had you invested ₹20000 in ethereum then,you would have reaped ₹1 lakh in less than a year.

Wait that is not all. Numerous forecasts go along with Vitalik Buterin,the founder of ethereum, predicting ethereum to surge to an astonishing $1300 by the end of 2020!

We have to hold back a second.Such surges are an innate feature of any commodity valuation.In retrospect,in January 2018 the great crypto crash ensued,plummeting the value of Bitcoin:the godfather of all cryptos,taking down other rivals alongside.Since then, the market has come a long way.

But what sets the market apart this time is the steady but strong appreciation of the cryptos. Seems good,nevertheless we can't help but wonder why people are ready to cash in millions for mere lines of program.

Image source: Coindesk

Let's dig a little deep.Any form of currency does not hold any intrinsic value.If you erase the print on a ₹50, €200 or a ¥100 it is just paper, it is the respective governments that guarantee their values.On the commodity front things are a little different,a bar of gold is worth the same in anywhere on the world irrespective of the embossing on it.Even so,it holds its value worth because humans deemed it valuable.

Crypto currencies are no different in this aspect,they have a price tag because people think they are worthwhile,the enhanced security and decentralization(i.e there is no active organisation controlling their value) add up to the appeal owing to which close to half of the total volume of cryptocurrencies are used as medium of exchange,replacing cash.The other half is what lands in the hands of investors.

The very uncertainty that ravaged the stocks could be the reason that is nourishing the virtual currencies.The Indian stock market crashed in April 2020 and several others around the world exchanges couldn’t escape the fate,investors have started to look into alternative investments to consolidate their wealth.This shift followed suit after the recent halving of bitcoin.Halving is the periodic reduction in the crypto coin minting in order to retain the upward trend.Another reason for the spike could be attributed to the legalization of bank assets in the form of cryptocurrencies,by the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency(OCC) in the US.

The road ahead: While the number of merchants and consumers, approving and accepting cryptocurrencies have been growing,they are still very much in the minority.Although conservative speculation prevails in the cryptocurrency,the consistent performance coupled with the investor confidence unfold an immediate future that is nothing short of bright for investment.

Should I invest in bitcoin explain.

Bitcoin is extremely volatile, but if you are willing to take the risk, first make sure you understand what you are investing in and have a crypto investment strategy.

Also make sure you aren’t investing simply because you have a fear missing out. There are a number of questions you should ask yourself before getting involved:

  1. Do I understand what I am investing in and how bitcoin works?
  2. Am I happy with the level of risk?
  3. How much more expensive is it now compared to a few months ago? If so, why am I wanting to buy a thing because its price is higher? Where else in my life do I do that?
  4. Is there any evidence to suggest prices could rise even higher?
  5. If I buy it now with a view to sell it for even more later, who do I think will buy it from me for that higher price and why?
  6. If an asset is so great, why was I not interested when it was much cheaper?
  7. Have I convinced myself that I am in some way “in the know?”

If you don’t have answers to these questions, it’s probably not a good idea to invest. If you do buy bitcoin, make sure you aren’t putting money you need on the line.

Find out more: Cryptocurrency tips (and mistakes to avoid)

Bitcoin: Common Mistakes to Avoid and How to Invest in Bitcoin

Bitcoin is a popular digital asset and payment system. Transactions are verified through cryptography and recorded in a public dispersed ledger called a blockchain. Bitcoin is unique but you need to know to use it and avoid mistakes.

Here are some common mistakes bitcoin rookies make.

1. Understanding and Bitcoin

Many people jump into bitcoin without fully understanding what it is or how it works. This can lead to confusion and frustration. So if you’re new to bitcoin, take the time to learn about it before start using it.

2. Secure and Bitcoin

Like any other digital asset, bitcoin is susceptible to hackers and theft. So it’s important to secure your bitcoin. This includes using a strong password, encrypting your wallet, and backing up your wallet.

3. Buying A Lot Of Bitcoin

It can be tempting to buy a lot of bitcoin when prices are low. But doing this can be risky, especially if you’re not familiar with the market. It’s best to buy bitcoin in small doses and learn about the market before investing more money.

4. Margin Trading

Margin trading can be dangerous, especially for novice traders. When you trade on margin, you’re borrowing money from your broker to increase your buying power. This can lead to large losses if the market moves against you.

5. Not Researching the Coins - Avoid Scams

Before investing in a new coin, do your research and make sure you understand what it is and what it’s trying to achieve. There are a lot of scams out there, so it’s important to be careful when trading coins.

It's hard to add onto Darren Duane who wrote an incredibly insightful answer. A lot of attention has been focused on the price of Bitcoin which has exhibited extreme volatility, moving from highs of $1,000+ per coin in the end of 2013 to ~$230 as of April 2015. Price is simply the equilibrium point between demand and supply and doesn't necessarily reflect the value of an asset's worth. As an inspiring venture and value investor, I believe it is important to understand the fundamentals before investing in anything.

Instead, we should look at the fundamental factors that drive value in the Bitcoin ecosystem. Pantera Capital's Bitindex, which captures developer interest, merchant adoption, user adoption, and transaction volume, does a great job at summarizing the growing ecosystem and reveals that the Bitcoin ecosystem has grown more than 3.5x (In April 2015) since 2012. In addition, there has been an unprecedented amount of Venture Capital funding Bitcoin startups - over $650 million to date (according to Coindesk's statistics). There is obvious momentum in Bitcoin - but how do we decide whether we want to invest?

That will depend on your view of Bitcoin and where things are headed. The most bullish on Bitcoin adamantly believe Bitcoin will serve as the world's payment rail and that Bitcoin will unearth all existing financial and legal systems. Those bullish expect Bitcoin to hit $10k or $100k+ in the next few years. The flip side of the coin includes individuals who believe BTC would not amount to much, besides serve a niche community. This case still requires users to utilize Bitcoin as its plumbing and price could decease to levels in 2012.

Personally, I'm optimistic about Bitcoin and its potential to change financial and legal industries. I think the result will be somewhere between the two extremes described above.

Disclaimer: I own a number of Bitcoins and am not an investment advisor.

Blockchain technology and smart contracts will eventually replace and disintermediate the current banking transfer monopolies.

It will not replace banks or exchanges.

But it will disintermediate with prejudice the 2–3% credit card business, or the 6% PayPal model...

Will Bitcoin be the solution? Probably not. But blockchain technologies will be.

Bitcoin is the best known blockchain technology. That means absolutely nothing and absolutely everything.

Bitcoin is like Wordperfect and Lotus 123. Revolutionary. But not the final say in the blockchain evolution.

MS Office will eventually (very soon, if not already) be considered an impediment to collaborative productivity.

The current payment infrastructure is more like trying to configure a Novell network to print Wordperfect documents to a common HP Laserjet II.

Novell was so obtuse in its interface that just knowing how to configure it payed for skool (and all manner of delinquent ungentlemanly behavior).

Obtuse describes perfectly the Bitcoin experience.

Yes, you should invest time and effort at understanding blockchain technologies.

Because its the biggest opportunity in tech right now.
