You should be very conservative while investing in asset like bitcoin. This is because of following reasons:-

  1. volatility rate of bitcoin is very high leaing to increase in risk. This rate is high because there is no regulatory authority to control it like we have RBI in case of INR.
  2. It is very difficult to determine true value of a bitcoin like if we invest in equity of any company then we can analyse the value of the share through its fundamentals.
  3. This is the kind of a asset which is backed by nothing like in case of bank deposits or INR, it is backed by RBI.
  4. It is banned by various nations.
  5. It is not being traded over any authorised exchange i.e. In case of equity, they are traded over NSE/BSE recognised by SEBI, so, if there is any dispute arising in future time, there will be no one to settle it making your investment zero.
  6. This is kind of peer to peer transaction without any third party being involved like if u want to issue someone a cheque then bank will be the third party in transaction but in this, since there is no party to guarantee the payment, your investment will be at all time risk.

I'll play Devils advocate here. I've been doing a fair amount of research on blockchain so I feel comfortable discussing it's merits and use for the future. I do not like your reference to the dot com bubble. How is the "dot com" bubble doing? It's dream was to change everything. I don't think anyone could make a valid argument that it hasn't. Of course there were losers along the way. There always is with new technologies. But in the long term the technology has been proven and is growing even more into our lives. There are patchy start ups and pyramid scheme'ish looking companies being introduced for an example check out bitconnect. These "quick buck" companies will without a doubt come crashing down if they don't act with integrity. But in what world are there no losers when a new technology comes into play? We need losers just as much as winners. It makes the system stronger and weeds out all the fluff.

Payment technologies are a huge business sector. After all payments need to be safe. What if the system we set up is backwards? Anyone with my piece of plastic that represents my bank account can use it if they have it, that doesn't seem right. Identity theft is also a major industry, do our names and personal information really need to be connected to our money? Fraud is huge, so is counter fitting, now people are creating fake gold, credit card skimmers, the list goes on and on. We pay a ton of money to keep our money "safe" just look how many financial institutions there are. How about the almost monthly massive data breaches we here about? Where everyone's informations is compromised, To me it seems the way money is transferred needs a major overhaul. It is inefficient, expensive, unsafe, and people are getting burned.

In steps blockchain, a global currency that is easily transferable between peers or businesses. Open ledgers that are verified between many networks and cannot be tampered with, counterfeited, or changed in any way. Money is transferred with pennies in fees, anywhere in the world. For the argument in huge national tragedies it would be worthless I guess I don't understand? What if the world burns down they will be worth nothing? We could play what if all day long. But the global value stays the same. I could trade bitcoin to an area not phased by natural disaster for goods or services. Could you do that with fiat money? It would be a lot harder to do. For example if I have a relative in Singapore that needs money pronto. I could send any amount in seconds. How would your relative fare? You would go to western union or something and pay huge fees with some transfer rate and wait for international money transfer verification for idk days and then they would have to find an open western union in a national disaster?? I think I like my situation more.

I'll leave it at that for now as this is getting long. But I would encourage anyone to have an open mind to new technologies rather than shutting it down right away as a fraud just because it is too successful. I think the future could be bright here. The U.S. is usually pretty open to new technologies I don't think they'll ever try to shut this down just because it's new.

Disclaimer: I do own a small amount of bitcoin

I’ve been watching this bitcoin situation for a few years, assuming it would just blow over.

But a collective insanity has sprouted around the new field of “cryptocurrencies”, causing an irrational gold rush worldwide. It has gotten to the point where a large number of financial stories – and questions in my inbox – ask whether or not to “invest” in BitCoin.

Let’s start with the answer: no. You should not invest in Bitcoin.

The reason why is that it’s not an investment; just as gold, tulip bulbs, Beanie Babies, and rare baseball cards are also not investments.

These are all things that people have bought in the past, driving them to absurd prices, not because they did anything useful or produced money or had social value, but solely because people thought they could sell them on to someone else for more money in the future.

When you make this kind of purchase – which you should never do – you are speculating. This is not a useful activity. You’re playing a psychological, win-lose battle against other humans with money as the sole objective. Even if you win money through dumb luck, you have lost time and energy, which means you have lost.

I’ll answer this question from a slightly different perspective, purely from an investment perspective. Then I’ll address some points others have made because.

If you’re only interested in making money, your decision is simple. From today until the day you plan to sell bitcoin, do you think the price will rise more quickly than any other thing you can buy? If so, then invest in bitcoin. If not, buy something else.

So, will the price of bitcoin rise more quickly than other things you can buy?

Yes.

Here’s why:

  1. Bitcoin developers have released the Lightning Network. With Lightning Network, you will be able to send bitcoin at virtually no cost. In fact, the cost are so low that the Lightning Network engineers had to develop a new way to account for the costs (bitcoin only goes to 8 decimal places, and fees could be as little as .000000000000001 bitcoin). This will make bitcoin very easy to transact with, and simple for anybody to create their own payment solutions using bitcoin as a free (or almost-free) payment network. In fact, Bakkt has stated this is one of its objectives, and Starbucks invested in the platform for that very reason. Once merchants realize they can eliminate the 1–3% fees and costs of $.09 per transaction by switching from Square or Visa or PayPal to a bitcoin-backed payment system, they will. And the demand for bitcoin will skyrocket, along with bitcoin’s price.
  2. There are many projects and lots of development going on to improve bitcoin. These projects aim to lower costs, increase speed, enable more transactions per second, and better regulate the market. These improvements will make bitcoin more valuable, which will probably lead to people being willing to pay more for it.
  3. Large investors and investment firms are quietly buying bitcoin. I’ve written about this in other answers, with evidence, as have other writers. It’s an open secret. In the past, when large investors have moved quietly into an investment, they soon market the investment heavily—promotions, ads, “training,” etc. And as a result, people buy it.
  4. Financial institutions are making it easy for people to buy bitcoin as part of their traditional investment accounts. TD Ameritrade and Robinhood have already done this for individual investors, Goldman Sachs and Coinbase are doing this for institutional investors, and both Bank of America and JP Morgan have said publicly that there’s a lot of demand for these “safe” ways to buy crypto. If they’re right, you’re going to see a lot of money move into this space in the coming years (maybe months).

You also need to consider the cryptocurrency market as a whole. You have a $200 billion market chasing $200 trillion to $1 quadrillion worth of value. Anything of value can be stored on a blockchain, with a cryptocurrency the only way to extract value from it. While it’s impossible to predict which cryptocurrencies will see the biggest increase from today’s price, cryptocurrencies as a whole have no place to go but up (long term). Many will fail—possibly bitcoin may fail, too—but the ones that succeed will solve a problems so big that even if they’re modestly successful, their value will skyrocket. To get into the crypto market, you need to buy bitcoin. Therefore, as more people get interested in the crypto market, they’ll buy bitcoin, and the price will go up.

Also look at your overall investment strategy. You should always own some “non-correlated assets” that sometimes boom. Bitcoin is a non-correlated asset—its price moves independently from other asset classes (i.e., real estate, bonds, stocks, etc). Putting a small portion of your total wealth in these assets will give you a low-risk way to boost the performance of your overall investment portfolio. If the price goes to the moon, you can sell your bitcoin for cash. If the price craps out, you lose very little. Learn About Why Asset Correlation Matters.

I also believe that the tax and regulatory situation around cryptocurrencies will change over the next few years. In the US, at least a certain amount of cryptocurrency spending will not be subject to capital gains or losses. I also think there’s an outside chance the US will legislate sweeping regulatory reform regarding crypto, like we did for the Internet in the early 90s. Too many rich, powerful interests stand to make too much money and they don’t want the government to screw this up for them. Can you imagine buying an asset today knowing you might be able to use it tax-free in a few years?

For more of my perspective, read these other answers I’ve written:

  • Mark Helfman's answer to Do you think bitcoin will reach 100k, or are these people online just bluffing? Seems to be dropping fast with no sign of coming up.
  • Mark Helfman's answer to With most stocks being considered overvalued, is cryptocurrency a good place to invest?
  • Mark Helfman's answer to What is the hardest thing for people outside of crypto community to understand about blockchain or cryptocurrency?

Regarding other Quora comments:

“The only reason to buy bitcoin is to sell it to somebody else for more than you bought it for.”

This is not true.

You can also bitcoin for its intended purpose—sending money to anybody, anywhere, in any amount, anytime, instantly and with certainty that you will receive exactly what you ask for without giving out sensitive personal information, bribing anybody, or risking theft while your wealth changes hands. There is no other way to send money that way.

That’s the intrinsic value of bitcoin. How much is that worth? The markets will decide. You have no control over that.

I suggest you buy a little bitcoin—use the Abra wallet on your phone, not an exchange. With Abra, you have full control over your bitcoin. Then use it. Understand how it works. You will feel more comfortable with your decision whether to invest or not. You will also have perspective that most of the world does not have.

If you only buy and sell bitcoin and never use it, you will never understand the convenience, security, and cost-savings of sending money directly to other people without needing a bank account or cash—you will simply wonder why anybody would want to own a bunch of numbers on a screen. Just like if you only buy and sell stocks and never hold them in your portfolio, you will never understand the satisfaction of collecting dividends and owning a share of a business—you will simply wonder why anybody would give up real money in exchange for an IOU from a corporation that could fail or go bankrupt. Just like if you only buy and sell theater tickets and never watch a show, you will never understand the power of emotional and intellectual stimulation—you will simply wonder why anybody would spend $50 or more to spend 2 hours sitting in darkness watching other people pretend to do things. You will see only price, not value. Maybe you’ll decide to invest in bitcoin, stocks, and theaters, or maybe you won’t—but you’ll make that decision based on your own thoughts and observations, not the movement of lines on a price chart or Quora answers.

“Bitcoin’s bubble burst.”

This might be true but I doubt it.

Look at this classic “anatomy of a bubble” chart:

Some people think that chart shows 2017’s “boom” — but it doesn’t. We haven’t reached true boom, just the first sell off. Only 2–8 percent of people own cryptocurrency, depending on what survey you believe. More people own fidget spinners. 2–8 percent is not a craze, it’s just media hype.

Perspective: the price of bitcoin has had many extreme upswings and declines. In fact, this is the norm for all cryptocurrency—up 1,000% then down 67% then up 1,000% then down 67% is just the way the prices move. See for yourself:

Bitcoin (BTC) price, charts, market cap, and other metrics | CoinMarketCap

Many cryptocurrencies are more valuable now than before the so-called bubble. In fact, bitcoin’s price is up 25% compared to this time last year, 600% compared to this time in 2016. The speed and intensity of bitcoin’s price action is simply insane, but just because something’s volatile doesn’t make it a bubble and just because it goes down doesn’t mean it’s dead.

There are many projects and lots of development going on to improve the cryptocurrencies in general. These projects aim to lower costs, increase speed, enable more transactions per second, and better regulate the market. Bakkt, alt-coin breakthroughs, IBM/XLM combo, blockchain-enabled secondary markets, blockchain-enabled financial and social networks, crypto businesses, cryptocurrency custodians, other advancements in blockchain technology…I could go on! Bitcoin will benefit because, as stated above, everybody needs to buy bitcoin to get into the crypto space.

“Bitcoin is too expensive to be useful.”

This is relative. Two points to be made.

First, businesses pay a lot of money to send and receive money. They pass these costs on to you, the customer. you never see them, but the business owners do. It costs between 1–3% plus $.09 per transaction, on average, to handle electronic payments. MoneyGram charges you to send money overseas (up to 15%). Your bank charges you to wire money (mine charges $15). Amazon does not charge you to use a credit card—instead, Amazon covers the costs and doesn’t even tell you about it. But somebody always pays.

Bitcoin eliminates those costs, but passes the burden onto the sender instead of the business. As I write, it costs about 20 cents USD to send bitcoin from my Abra wallet. With Lightning Network, it costs less than one-thousandth of a cent USD. With a Bakkt- or Coinbase-based payment solution, it may end up being totally free.

Second, it’s less expensive to buy and sell bitcoin than other types of assets. Bitcoin wallet providers will charge 1–2 percent to convert your cash into bitcoin, which is in line with retail stockbrokers and comparable to online brokers on average ($7 fee for a $700 purchase of stock is no unusual). It costs a lot less than real estate (5–10% total costs) or gold (2–3% commission plus transportation fees).

Also, there’s no minimum or maximum amount you can buy or sell, you have lots of people/businesses who can get you into the market for free, and it costs nothing to store.

Bitcoin is a non-correlated asset—its price moves independently from other asset classes (i.e., real estate, bonds, stocks, etc). Putting a small portion of your total wealth in these assets will give you a low-risk way to boost the performance of your overall investment portfolio. If the price goes to the moon, you can sell your bitcoin for cash. If the price craps out, you lose very little. Learn About Why Asset Correlation Matters.

I also believe that the tax and regulatory situation around cryptocurrencies will change over the next few years. In the US, at least a certain amount of cryptocurrency spending will not be subject to capital gains or losses. I also think there’s an outside chance the US will legislate sweeping regulatory reform regarding crypto, like we did for the Internet in the early 90s. Too many rich, powerful interests stand to make too much money and they don’t want the government to screw this up for them. Can you imagine buying an asset today knowing you might be able to use it tax-free in a few years?

Regarding other Quora comments:
“The only reason to buy bitcoin is to sell it to somebody else for more than you bought it for.”
This is not true.

You can also bitcoin for its intended purpose—sending money to anybody, anywhere, in any amount, anytime, instantly and with certainty that you will receive exactly what you ask for without giving out sensitive personal information, bribing anybody, or risking theft while your wealth changes hands. There is no other way to send money that way.
That’s the intrinsic value of bitcoin. How much is that worth? The markets will decide. You have no control over that.

I suggest you buy a little bitcoin—use the Abra wallet on your phone, not an exchange. With Abra, you have full control over your bitcoin. Then use it. Understand how it works. You will feel more comfortable with your decision whether to invest or not. You will also have perspective that most of the world does not have.

If you only buy and sell bitcoin and never use it, you will never understand the convenience, security, and cost-savings of sending money directly to other people without needing a bank account or cash—you will simply wonder why anybody would want to own a bunch of numbers on a screen. Just like if you only buy and sell stocks and never hold them in your portfolio, you will never understand the satisfaction of collecting dividends and owning a share of a business—you will simply wonder why anybody would give up real money in exchange for an IOU from a corporation that could fail or go bankrupt. Just like if you only buy and sell theater tickets and never watch a show, you will never understand the power of emotional and intellectual stimulation—you will simply wonder why anybody would spend $50 or more to spend 2 hours sitting in darkness watching other people pretend to do things. You will see only price, not value. Maybe you’ll decide to invest in bitcoin, stocks, and theaters, or maybe you won’t—but you’ll make that decision based on your own thoughts and observations, not the movement of lines on a price chart or Quora answers.
“Bitcoin’s bubble burst.”
This might be true but I doubt it.
Look at this classic “anatomy of a bubble” chart:

Some people think that chart shows 2017’s “boom” — but it doesn’t. We haven’t reached true boom, just the first sell off. Only 2–8 percent of people own cryptocurrency, depending on what survey you believe. More people own fidget spinners. 2–8 percent is not a craze, it’s just media hype.

Perspective: the price of bitcoin has had many extreme upswings and declines. In fact, this is the norm for all cryptocurrency—up 1,000% then down 67% then up 1,000% then down 67% is just the way the prices move. See for yourself:
Bitcoin (BTC) price, charts, market cap, and other metrics | CoinMarketCap

Many cryptocurrencies are more valuable now than before the so-called bubble. In fact, bitcoin’s price is up 25% compared to this time last year, 600% compared to this time in 2016. The speed and intensity of bitcoin’s price action is simply insane, but just because something’s volatile doesn’t make it a bubble and just because it goes down doesn’t mean it’s dead.

There are many projects and lots of development going on to improve the cryptocurrencies in general. These projects aim to lower costs, increase speed, enable more transactions per second, and better regulate the market. Bakkt, alt-coin breakthroughs, IBM/XLM combo, blockchain-enabled secondary markets, blockchain-enabled financial and social networks, crypto businesses, cryptocurrency custodians, other advancements in blockchain technology…I could go on! Bitcoin will benefit because, as stated above, everybody needs to buy bitcoin to get into the crypto space.
“Bitcoin is too expensive to be useful.”
This is relative. Two points to be made.

First, businesses pay a lot of money to send and receive money. They pass these costs on to you, the customer. you never see them, but the business owners do. It costs between 1–3% plus $.09 per transaction, on average, to handle electronic payments. MoneyGram charges you to send money overseas (up to 15%). Your bank charges you to wire money (mine charges $15). Amazon does not charge you to use a credit card—instead, Amazon covers the costs and doesn’t even tell you about it. But somebody always pays.

Bitcoin eliminates those costs, but passes the burden onto the sender instead of the business. As I write, it costs about 20 cents USD to send bitcoin from my Abra wallet. With Lightning Network, it costs less than one-thousandth of a cent USD. With a Bakkt- or Coinbase-based payment solution, it may end up being totally free.

Second, it’s less expensive to buy and sell bitcoin than other types of assets. Bitcoin wallet providers will charge 1–2 percent to convert your cash into bitcoin, which is in line with retail stockbrokers and comparable to online brokers on average ($7 fee for a $700 purchase of stock is no unusual). It costs a lot less than real estate (5–10% total costs) or gold (2–3% commission plus transportation fees).
Also, there’s no minimum or maximum amount you can buy or sell, you have lots of people/businesses who can get you into the market for free, and it costs nothing to store.

Don’t take anyone’s advice about what will happen with the currency. do your own homework, learn about Bitcoin and come to a conclusion for yourself.

A few pointers for buying and holding Bitcoins:

Never invest more than you are willing/able to lose – Bitcoin is a very risky investment and you should keep that in mind at all times. After buying Bitcoins, make sure to move them into your own Bitcoin wallet and never leave them on an exchange. If we’re talking about substantial amounts, my personal recommendation is to use a hardware wallet. If you can’t afford a hardware wallet, try a paper wallet. Make sure to buy Bitcoins only from Reputable Bitcoin exchanges. Sometimes paying a little extra is worth the security and piece of mind. Use Dollar cost averaging (DCA) – This means that you don’t buy all of your Bitcoins in one trade but instead buy a fixed amount every month, week or even day throughout the year. This way you average the price over the course of a whole year

Plenty of other answers to this, but to add my satoshi's worth…

  1. You'll drive yourself insane thinking about coulda-woulda-shoulda. I should have invested in Bitcoin in 2010. I should have bought Apple stock in 2002, I should have put £1000 on Leicester City winning the Premier League. Don't beat yourself up. Few people have big money to throw around on outset shots. Just tip your hat to the visionaries and chancers.
  2. On that point, don't buy BTC to day-trade. “Buy low, sell high” right? Trust me, it ain't that easy. You'll quickly fall foul. What looks like the bottom is never the bottom and the top is never the top. Most day trading now is done by computers run by institutions who would have you for breakfast. If you buy BTC, buy it to…
  3. HOLD! Seriously, transfer it to a hardware wallet, stick it in a safe.place somewhere and forget about it for a decade or two. Watching the price bounce up and down is an emotional rollercoaster. One day you're up five grand, the next day you've lost two. But Bitcoin's scarcity model should mean that over the long-term, it's price will continue to rise. Is this guaranteed? No. Which is why…
  4. Don't invest what you can't afford to lose. It's volatility is maddening and makes it incredibly risky. Huge potential rewards but devastating potential loses. Diversification is important with any investment plan. If Bitcoin collapsed tomorrow, would your kids be eating out of rubbish bins next week? Has your retirement suddenly gone from sailing the world in a 100 foot yacht to scrounging for pennies out of payphones? Think of Bitcoin as the “wildcard” in your investment portfolio.
  5. Dollar Cost Averaging (DCA) is a way of investing in Bitcoin without stressing about volatility. It means to buy very small portions regularly over a long period of time. Your investment is then less sensitive to the ups and downs you'd get with a massive lump sum
  6. Ask yourself why? FOMO? Greed? Because you really believe in the idea of a decentralised currency? Because you think fiat is doomed and want to have contingency for when they all collapse? Be honest, and invest accordingly.

It would be best if you considered investing in Bitcoin alongside other cryptocurrencies. Many cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin, Litecoin, and Ethereum, among others, enable payments globally through their respective blockchains. Check out below some points where I have discussed why you should invest in Bitcoin and other cryptos.

Well-established cryptos: Bitcoin is the first cryptocurrency and has existed for a long time. There are also many other cryptocurrencies similar to Bitcoin that have launched and might be an improvement to Bitcoin. Hence you might want to buy a basket of cryptocurrencies instead of your one cryptocurrency (diversification is always great). If you are planning to invest in the long-term, you should select the fundamentally sound cryptocurrencies that you believe have the best potential in the long term. Next, you have to choose some investment apps or exchanges to buy Bitcoin and the other crypto.

Available resources: To invest in crypto, you must learn and get proper guidance. You must read about the investment process and fundamentals of cryptocurrency. There are a lot of resources online. There are many apps that can provide you guidance on how to invest in crypto, so you need to select the one you trust. Some apps recommend which crypto to buy at a given time.

Opportunities: You have an opportunity to invest in other cryptos if you have Bitcoin. Bitcoin can be exchanged against other cryptos (a pair). Create accounts in multiple reliable exchanges or one investment app integrated with many reliable exchanges. Then wait for the right time to buy the cryptocurrencies or use a recommendation platform that can recommend when to buy. Once you have purchased the cryptocurrencies, you need to wait for the perfect time to sell the cryptocurrencies and purchase other cryptocurrencies. You might need a solution that automates the process. You should be able to withdraw any cryptocurrency easily.

Bitcoin is extremely volatile. If you are willing to take the risk, first make sure you understand what you are investing in and have a crypto investment strategy.

Also make sure you aren’t investing simply because you have a fear of missing out.There are a number of questions you should ask yourself before getting involved:

  1. Do I understand what I am investing in and how bitcoin and the crypto market work?
  2. Am I happy with the level of risk?
  3. How much more expensive is it now compared to a few months ago? If so, why am I wanting to buy a thing because its price is higher? Where else in my life do I do that?
  4. Is there any evidence to suggest prices could rise even higher?
  5. If I buy it now with a view to sell it for even more later, who do I think will buy it from me for that higher price and why?
  6. If an asset is so great, why was I not interested when it was much cheaper

Experts Say Bitcoin Could Hit $100,000 In 2022. Here’s What Investors Should Know

It’s been a rocky start to the year for Bitcoin, but experts still say it will hit $100,000 — and that it’s more a matter of when not if.

Bitcoin’s price plunged below $33,000 Monday, continuing a descent that began at the tail end of last week and persisted throughout the weekend. The leading crypto saw a brief rally on May 4, primarily driven by the Federal Reserve’s announcement that it is raising its benchmark interest rate by half a percentage point, but those gains were quickly erased. The Fed signaled that it will continue raising rates aggressively in the coming months and begin reducing asset holdings on its $9 trillion balance sheet in June.

Investors continue to wrestle with concerns over rising inflation, geopolitical tensions, and the possibility of tighter monetary policy by the U.S. Federal Reserve. The crypto market has increasingly tracked the stock market in recent months, which makes it even more intertwined with global economic factors.

With no end in sight, the war, inflation, and shifting monetary policy in the U.S. will likely continue to drive more volatility in the coming weeks and months, experts say.

“The overall market has noticed the high correlation to Bitcoin and the general equities markets,” says Armando Aguilar, head of alternative strategies and research for Len, a digital asset savings and credit platform. “The S&P 500 and NASDAQ have had the largest correlations to Bitcoin with 0.88% and 0.91%, respectively. A correlation of one means that they move equally one to the other.”

Bitcoin has only been above $45,000 for a few short stretches over the past four months and hasn’t been above $50,000 since Dec. 25, 2021. Still, Bitcoin has stayed above its 6-month low below $34,000 in late January. Amid the ups and downs, Bitcoin’s current price is a long way off from the latest all-time high it hit in November when it went over $68,000. But even with the recent decline in price, Bitcoin is still more than twice as valuable as it was just a couple of years ago. For Bitcoin, these kinds of ups and downs are nothing new.

It can be profitable to invest in bitcoin for the long-term as we are only at the beginning of what could be a major cyclical trend in bitcoin applications and use cases. Just as holding some gold and silver to protect against paper currency devaluation makes sense, reserving your piece on the block chain now can be very wise since the market is nowhere near critical mass.

Of course, your average cost basis over time will matter but it really depends on your economic outlook for crypto-currencies in general and then bitcoin as the successful crypto-currency. I think decentralised cryptography-based digital bearer instruments are the next evolution for value transfer and I would definitely not want to be caught short.

TL;DR; Yes, atleast for the near future. If you are well read, You would know when you should stop investing.

Sam Williams What u said is partially true that the bubble will pop. But there have always been bubbles in fiat currencies which popped. People did not stop using it. They just resolved the bubbles and went back to their lives and needs. Nevertheless, there were people who lost "money".

You are using Quora, So I safely assume that you understand the concept of time-value for money. Any currency in this world will obviously increase in value with time. A commodity which was obtained today will come at a cheaper price later. That does not mean people do not buy commodities. Needs are what drive buying power more than value of the currency. It is just that these currencies deflate slowly and stably than bitcoin. But that is because there are a "HUGE" number of people using them compared to the bitcoin user-base. A large number of users will stabilize bitcoin too. We just have to wait for it.

The biggest challenge in Bitcoin economy is the policing required to track unwarranted activities. Hence the governments would be against the wide spread usage of it. Or maybe there will be a work around. And talking about taxes, I am sure the people will pay taxes willfully if they know that the levels of corruption will be far lesser with bitcoin.

P.S: I personally believe that a certain amount of regulation is definitely required to ensure smooth running of society.

Any comments are most welcome.

Bitcoin is probably best thought of as a place to store value. Generalizing greatly, it is similar to gold, euros or real estate. The value of all these things can vary greatly between the time they are bought or sold. As an investment, I think that I would like to quote J.P. Morgan regarding the stock market. "It will fluctuate". So I can't help you there other than to say buy low and sell high.

That being said, I believe that Bitcoin might be international banking and finance's 'MP3 moment". Digital audio compression disrupted the music industry eventually, Cell phones disrupted land lines and Uber has caused an 80% drop in business at cab companies in certain cities. All of this because new technologies and ideas can lead to radical business change. To say that there is money at stake regarding bitcoin is and understatement because transactional monetary fees are a trillion pound gorilla that everyone is trying to capture. And with so much money at stake, never count out in influence that money has on regulatory policies that could hamstring bitcoin and other crypto currencies.

And generally, I think it is possible that bitcoin will be the friendster of the space. I think there is still a facebook to come.

You should consider investing in Bitcoin a high risk investment. But that can be appropriate as part of your overall portfolio.

So let's say you have $100k to invest, you put 60% in stocks (diversified portfolio or S&P index), 20% in bonds 10% in cash and 10% in some high risk investment like Bitcoin. So you have to be comfortable, with losing that 10%. Maybe for you 5% or even 1% would be a better allocation. Bitcoin has shown that it can go down up and down in value rapidly. So you should be prepared and totally cool with that before investing. No one wants to lose money, but think of it as part of an overall investment strategy.

Also, if you do buy some bitcoins, be sure to spend some as well. This will help the bitcoin economy and ultimately increase the value of Bitcoin. So consider part of your investment as "spending money" to help aid the economy.

Cryptocurrencies are a fascinating idea. I expect that someday they will have a significant economic role. That being said, I don't think they qualify by any means as an investment at the present time. Some of the problems include:

  • Bitcoin legal status is undecided. Some countries have restricted or banned Bitcoin.
  • In the US, Bitcoin is considered property by the IRS. You will need to establish and report the cost basis of every purchase you make, when you pay your taxes.
  • Online exchanges are risky. See, for example, the cautionary tale of Mt. Gox, where almost $500 million was stolen.
  • As an unregulated and untraceable online currency, hackers are attracted to Bitcoin. Some of the attacks, like BGP hijacking of ISP traffic, are nearly impossible for an investor to defend against.
  • Bitcoin faces an existential threat in the form of miners taking 51 percent network share. A malicious group of miners could spend the same coins twice, reject other miners' transactions, or perform a denial of service against the entire network.

If all you want to do is mine some coin and store it in an offline wallet in the hope of future appreciation, I suppose that might be safe enough. But don't be like the guy who tossed out his hard drive containing $9 Million in Bitcoin

I would not recommend as a financial investment – it is highly speculative.

I would however recommend "investing" time and effort into learning about and using small amounts of bitcoin until you really understand it. Bitcoin is still a young experiment and it's unclear what real benefits it will bring for the average person (aka it is a "solution looking for a problem").

That being said, I do own some myself, but accept the fiat value could easily lose 90% overnight. This is a risk I fully understand and am willing to make to be a part of something that could change the world. If you are paranoid about hyperinflation of fiat, then buying some bitcoin might make sense for you as well.

Remember, Bitcoin works the same way at $10 / bitcoin as it does at $10,000. A higher exchange rate just helps with liquidity, but Bitcoin works the same way regardless of what happens at the exchanges.

answers.html:
Yes, of course you should! The only real question here is : How much you should ‘invest’?

Also if you are talking specifically about bitcoin only, then try to think of it more as a way of saving, because you are not paid a dividend, you are more hoping for sheer capital appreciation.

Like most investments and savings strategies one of the main things to consider are ‘opportunity costs’ and especially as far as savings are concerned, if you have the choice between Bitcoin and a savings account, then bitcoin wins. Also taking into account the expanding money supply in dollars and pounds and euro's currently the value of people's savings is shrinking, even if the numerical value isn't.

Try not to base your decision on the ramblings of the people who cannot see Bitcoins intrinsic values, which are the ability to be duplicated and observered from anywhere in the world without being interfered with, without the owners explicit consent. Only the sun shares this features.

Bitcoin is not stealable, anyone who points you towards high profile hacks is only showing you weaknesses in a certain public companies security. This is the literal equivalent of blaming dollars for a bank heist. What you need to be told is that when this money is hacked, everybody knows where It's gone, and nobody can do anything to get it back, this includes government agencies and bounty hunters. Only further proving how safe your investment is, if stored properly. Remember if you don't own the private keys, you don't own the bitcoin.

You should definitely get some bitcoin and put your skin in the game. Only a small amount of you worry about theft, just to help you learn about the technology behind it. Then you can start to consider dividend paying cryptos and bitcoins other competitors which have different features and growth potential and are probably more investment worthy than Bitcoin itself.

Most of all, look for facts in people's arguments, not opinions based on points of view.

Good luck

answers.html:
Investing in Bitcoin is viable option especially in a view of current decline of the power of Fiat currencies. You can make profits with Bitcoin simply by following a DCA strategy, which is a low-risk strategy suitable to most investors.

You can increase your ROI by participating in Bitcoin mining and/or staking, though at this point mining other crypto currencies is more profitable than concentrating on Bitcoin or Ether.

Keep in mind that cryptocurrency market is extremely volatile, so you should be prepared for long-term investing rather than trying to concentrate on quick profit.

Before investing in Bitcoin, think about your storage preferences first. How do you want to store your Bitcoin? is it going to be a hard wallet or a soft wallet. Each of these options have their pros and cons.

With hard wallet, your Bitcoin is safe from hackers, however if you lose your usb drive, then your Bitcoin balance is gone forever. With soft wallets, you can restore your balance providing you have the private key, but at the same time there is a chance your balance could be stolen if either your wallet or the crypto site hosting your wallet are hacked…

None of these options is safe proof. However, keeping your money in Fiat currency is even worse choice. Not only you are getting close to 0 interest rate from banks, but insane inflation will quickly eat up your principal.
